docs.lead_paragraph: This Sunday found me having a very unpleasant conversation with two of my favorite men.

headline.main: Like a Fish Needs a Donut

docs.abstract: Older guys, younger babes, and the madwoman in the attic.
docs.snippet: Older guys, younger babes, and the madwoman in the attic.

docs.lead_paragraph: Last night's fundraiser at the U.N. for Unicef and Malawi was a wild end to an eventful day. At one point yesterday I was in a café on 10th Avenue, having a lonely bowl of minestrone and listening on the phone to a designer rant (didn't like the review: O.K.), and the next I was squeezing into the throng at the United Nations behind Tom Cruise and Katie Holmes. This was a little surreal. I mean, I've seen Cruise and Holmes at other parties. I remember seeing Cruise at a Vanity Fair Oscar party when he was married to Nicole Kidman. But it was funny seeing him last night, because Demi Moore swept up with Ashton Kushner and gave Cruise a big bear hug. I stepped around them, and saw Gwyneth Paltrow. People had that deer-in-the-headlights look: "It's Gwyneth." I thought she looked beautiful. I saw Narciso Rodriguez and Diane von Furstenberg, who was with her husband Barry Diller. The place was packed. The dinner crowd moved into a tent set up on the U.N. lawn, and, as Madonna reminded everyone, when she made her speech, we weren't technically in the United States anymore.
docs.abstract: Madonna and Gwyneth Paltrow at fundraiser at the U.N. for Unicef and Malawi. docs.lead_paragraph: Researchers have found for the first time that the incidence of the virus among breast-fed infants can be significantly reduced by using antiretroviral drugs for up to six months.

headline.main: Longer Drug Regimen Found to Help Babies Avoid H.I.V.

docs.lead_paragraph: A new Web site, Japander.com, catalogs Japanese ads featuring Western actors, like Harrison Ford drinking Kirin beer or Charlize Theron selling Lux products
